skill.name: pricing-strategy
skill.description: When the user wants help with pricing decisions, packaging, or monetization strategy. Also use when the user mentions 'pricing,' 'pricing tiers,' 'freemium,' 'free trial,' 'packaging,' 'price increase,' 'value metric,' 'Van Westendorp,' 'willingness to pay,' or 'monetization.' This skill covers pricing research, tier structure, and packaging strategy.
skill.summary: Expert guidance on SaaS pricing decisions, packaging structure, and monetization strategy.
skill.author: coreyhaines31

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The skill contains only markdown documentation with ASCII diagrams and text examples. Detected patterns include: backtick characters in markdown code blocks (misidentified as shell commands), SAML authentication references (misidentified as Windows SAM database), and survey methodology terminology (misidentified as cryptographic hashes). No executable code present.

content.value_statement: SaaS businesses struggle to price their products effectively. This skill provides frameworks for pricing research, tier structuring, and monetization strategy to capture customer value and drive growth.
actual_capabilities: Analyze pricing using Van Westendorp Price Sensitivity Meter
Design tier structures using Good-Better-Best framework
Select appropriate value metrics aligned with customer value
Develop freemium and free trial conversion strategies
Plan and communicate price increases effectively
limitations: Does not provide real-time competitor pricing data
Cannot access your internal financial metrics or customer data
Does not run actual surveys or collect willingness-to-pay data
Cannot implement pricing changes in your system

use_cases.title: New Product Pricing
use_cases.description: A founder launching a new SaaS product needs to set initial prices. Use Van Westendorp analysis and value-based pricing frameworks to determine optimal price points and tier structure.

use_cases.title: Pricing Tier Redesign
use_cases.description: A growing SaaS company wants to restructure its pricing tiers to capture more value. Design a Good-Better-Best framework based on feature utility and customer willingness to pay.

use_cases.title: Price Increase Planning
use_cases.description: An established SaaS business is ready to raise prices. Develop a strategy including grandfathering options, timing, and customer communication templates.

prompt_templates.title: Initial Pricing Assessment
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to set initial prices for a new SaaS product
prompt_templates.prompt:
Help me set pricing for my new SaaS product. Here is the context:
- Product type: [SaaS/marketplace/e-commerce/service]
- Target market: [SMB/mid-market/enterprise]
- Primary value delivered: [outcome]
- Main competitors: [alternatives]
- Current pricing (if any): [amount]

Guide me through the pricing research and framework process.

prompt_templates.title: Tier Structure Design
prompt_templates.scenario: User needs to design or redesign pricing tiers
prompt_templates.prompt:
I need to design pricing tiers for my SaaS product. Please help me:
- Determine the right number of tiers (2, 3, or 4)
- Create a Good-Better-Best structure
- Differentiate tiers by features, limits, or support
- Set appropriate price points based on value

Current product details: [features, target customers, competitive context]

prompt_templates.title: Value Metric Selection
prompt_templates.scenario: User is unsure what to charge for
prompt_templates.prompt:
Help me identify the right value metric for my pricing. My customers get value by:
- [how customers use product]
- [outcomes they achieve]
- [what they would pay more for]

Analyze these patterns and recommend whether I should price per user, per usage, per feature, or another metric.

prompt_templates.title: Price Increase Strategy
prompt_templates.prompt:
I want to raise my prices. Current situation:
- Current price: [amount]
- Monthly active users: [number]
- Churn rate: [percentage]
- Conversion rate: [percentage]
- Last pricing change: [when]
- New value delivered since then: [what]

Should I raise prices? What strategy should I use? Draft a customer communication.

output_examples.input: Help me price my project management SaaS for small teams. Target: SMBs, 5-50 employees. Current price: $15/user. Competitors range from $10-$30/user.
output_examples.output:
**Pricing Analysis for Project Management SaaS**

**Recommended Price Range: $18-24/user**

**Value-Based Framework:**
- Your differentiation value over $10 competitors: $8-12
- Next best alternative: $10
- Your cost to serve: ~$2

**Suggested Tier Structure:**
| Tier | Price | Target |
|------|-------|--------|
| Starter | $15/user | Teams just getting started |
| Pro | $20/user | Growing teams (recommended) |
| Business | $35/user | Larger teams with advanced needs |

**Key Insights:**
- Your $15 price is at the lower end, leaving value on table
- Recommend $20 as anchor price with clear value justification
- Consider annual discount (17-20%) to improve cash flow
- Test $24 with new customers before full rollout

output_examples.input: Our freemium conversion rate is only 2%. How can we improve it?
output_examples.output:
**Improving Freemium Conversion**

**Current State Assessment:**
- 2% conversion is below industry average (5-10% for good freemium)

**Diagnostic Questions:**
1. What triggers the upgrade prompt?
2. At what usage threshold do users upgrade?
3. What do non-converters do in the product?

**Improvement Strategies:**

1. **Clarify the Upgrade Trigger**
   - Freemium should have clear, painful limitations
   - Examples: message history limits, storage caps, team size limits

2. **Increase Perceived Value**
   - Show premium features but disable them
   - Use in-app messages highlighting premium benefits

3. **Time-Based Urgency**
   - 14-30 day window creates decision pressure
   - Countdown timers near trial end

4. **Segment High-Intent Users**
   - Identify power users through usage signals
   - Target upgrade messages to engaged free users

best_practices: Base prices on customer value delivered, not on your cost to serve or competitor prices alone.
Use pricing research methods like Van Westendorp surveys to understand willingness to pay before setting prices.
Test price increases with new customers first, then grandfather existing customers to reduce churn risk.
anti_patterns: Setting prices based solely on costs rather than customer value, which leaves money on the table.
Having too many pricing tiers that cause decision paralysis for buyers.
Raising prices for existing customers without grandfathering or clear value justification.

faq.question: How many pricing tiers should I have?
faq.answer: Most SaaS businesses succeed with 3 tiers (Good, Better, Best). Two tiers work for clear market splits. Avoid 4+ tiers as they create decision paralysis for buyers.

faq.question: What is the difference between freemium and free trial?
faq.answer: Freemium is a permanent free tier with limited features. Free trial is time-limited full access. Freemium works for viral products with low serving costs. Free trial works for complex products that need demonstration.

faq.question: How do I know if my prices are too low?
faq.answer: Signs prices are too low include: very high conversion rates, customer feedback about being cheap, competitors charging more, and customers using more than they pay for. Research shows 25-50% higher prices are often achievable.

faq.question: What value metric should I use?
faq.answer: A good value metric scales with customer value, is easy to understand, and is hard to game. Common options include per user (collaboration), per usage (infrastructure), per record (CRM), and revenue share (high-value outcomes).

faq.question: How do I communicate a price increase to customers?
faq.answer: Be transparent about why, give advance notice, grandfather existing customers if possible, and tie the increase to new value delivered. Provide a deadline for locking in old rates to drive action.

faq.question: Should I offer annual pricing discounts?
faq.answer: Yes, annual discounts of 17-20% improve cash flow and reduce churn. This works because annual commits lock in customers and improve your revenue predictability.
